note_text:
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:  Right lower lobe segmental obstruction 

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSES:
1.	Mucous plugging, with diffuse tracheobronchitis. 
2.	Mild Trachobronchiomlalacia 

PROCEDURE PERFORMED:  flexible bronchoscopy with bronchial washing
CONSCIOUS SEDATION:
1.  Fentanyl 100 mg IV push.
2.  Versed 4 mg IV push.

TOPICAL ANESTHESIA:  29 cc 1% lidocaine 

SPECIMENS SENT:

1.  Bronchial washing sent for cytology and culture
FINDINGS:  
DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE:  After appropriate consent was obtained from the patient, all risks and benefits were explained to him.  The patient was brought to the endoscopy suite and administered local anesthesia to the left naris and posterior pharynx.  This was then followed by administration of conscious sedation. The Olympus Q190 bronchoscope was then inserted through the left nare into the posterior oropharynx.   The vocal cords appeared to move normally during pronation. The bronchoscope was then passed into the trachea. Tthere appeared to be mild tracheomalacia as well as diffuse tracheobronchitis with boggy erythematous mucous extending throughout the right and left bronchial trees with thick yellow mucous seen throughout the airways. After suctioning of mucous plugs inspection was performed to at least the first subsegmental bronchi on all left and right sided airways. No endobronchial lesions were identified. The bronchoscope was then advanced to the right lower lobe and the bronchoscope was wedged into the lateral segment.  Bronchoalveolar lavage was then performed at this segment utilizing 90 mL of saline. The wedge was lost due to coughing and suction was reapplied yielding a bronchial wash rather than a true BAL. When this was completed, the airways were again inspected and no evidence of hemorrhage was seen.  The bronchoscope was withdrawn.  The patient tolerated the procedure well.  There were no complications.

 Recommendations:
1.	Await cytology and culture results.
2.	Repeat CT chest in 1 month to ensure resolution of radiographic findings.

metadata.notes: Procedure note transcribed; billing codes generated based on documentation.

note_text:
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: 
1.	Esophageal stent migration through distal trachea and left mainstem
2.	 Left mainstem occlusion secondary to  esophageal stent
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: 
1.	Tracheoesophageal fistula status post tracheal Y-stent placement
PROCEDURE PERFORMED: 
1.	Rigid bronchoscopy with esophageal stent removal 
2.	Dynamic Y ( hybrid) Tracheal stent placement
3.	Bronchoscopic intubation

INDICATIONS: left mainstem obstruction secondary to esophageal stent migration
Consent was obtained from the patient prior to procedure after explanation in lay terms the indications, details of procedure, and potential risks and alternatives. The patient acknowledged and gave consent. 
Sedation: General Anesthesia
DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE: The procedure was performed in the main operating room. After administration of sedatives an LMA was inserted and the T190 therapeutic flexible bronchoscope was passed through the vocal cords and into the trachea. Approximately 2 cm proximal to the main carina an esophageal stent was visualized protruding into the airway causing approximately 30% obstruction of the distal trachea. On closer inspection we could visualize both of the patients telescoping esophageal stent. The proximal end of the inner covered stent could be seen with the origin of the lumen approximately 50% into the airway. The outer uncovered stents proximal origin was seen about 5mm into the distal left mainstem. Additionally a large clip attached to the uncovered outer stent could be seen within the airway. The stents traversed into the left mainstem causing complete occlusion which we could not bypass with the flexible bronchoscope. Bronchial lavage was performed to collect purulent secretions from the airway. The flexible bronchoscope and LMA were then removed and a 14mm ventilating rigid bronchoscope was subsequently inserted into the mid trachea and connected to ventilator. Using flexible forceps we were able to detach and remove the clip. We were aware that the outer uncovered stent was embedded into the trachea and could not be removed. However, given that the inner stents proximal lumen was within the airway and that this stent was not known to be fixed to tissue we chose to attempt the remove the stent enblock through the airway. Using the rigid forceps the proximal edge of the stent was grasped and slowly withdrawn. Initially the stent moved easily however after retracting approximately 3cm of the stent sudden resistance was encountered and the proximal edge of the stent fractured. Given that a much longer segment of the stent was now within the trachea causing significant obstruction (which also now made placement of a tracheal stent impossible) we had no choice except to attempt to further extract the stent. The stent however was firmly fixed and retraction resulted in further fracture with multiple exposed sires within the trachea. Advanced GI endoscopy was called and came to the OR. The rigid bronchoscope was removed and an EGD was performed. The proximal edge of the outer uncovered stent  from the esophageal side was embedded and distorted and could not be passed even with the Ultra slim (6mm) gastroscope.  The rigid bronchoscope was reinserted during EGD to better allow us to visualize the communication and attempt to pass a wire in into the esophagus to place an additional stent but the wire would only pass into the airway and this was subsequently aborted leaving us no choice but to continue to remove the esophageal stent piecemeal. Using multiple techniques to include rigid endoscopic scissors, APC, and forceps we slowly removed exposed wires and attempted to transect the stent to allow airway stent placement. This was extremely difficult as more and more unraveling stent was seen. As both stents migrated further into the airway while extracting exposed wires the majority of the stents had to be removed in a piecemeal fashion. Once the stents were removed, with the exception of some small distal wires, the extent of the fistula (which extended during extraction) became completely apparent with the posterior wall of the trachea essentially absent in the lower third with a large defect at the main carina extending directly into the esophagus. We then attempted to place a 15x12x12 hybrid dynamic Y stent into the airway to occlude the fistula by removing the rigid bronchoscope and using glide-scope laryngoscopy visualizing the vocal cords and directly passing the stent, secured with Freitag forceps, into the trachea. Once the stent was within the airway we inserted a  rigid non-ventilating tracheoscope through the vocal cords proximal to the stent. Due to the large defect at the main carina it was extremely difficult to seat the limbs within the bilateral mainstem and despite multiple attempts utilizing rigid forceps, reverse forceps CRE balloons and manipulation with the tip of the flexible bronchoscope we could not adequately seat the stent. The stent was removed and we then attempted to place a smaller 13X10X10 mm dynamic Y with a 5.5cm tracheal limb, a 2cm right sided limb and a 3cm left sided limb using a similar technique and were eventually able to secure the stent in place. Once this was accomplished a 6.5 ETT was inserted into the airway over a bronchoscope and advanced into the proximal limb of the stent and secured in place.   
Complications:  Extension of TE fistula 
Recommendations:
-	Patient to remain on positive pressure ventilation tonight.
-	Please obtain CXR once patient arrives in ICU
-	Please obtain CT chest prior to extubation if possible 
-	Appreciate GI recommendations. 
-	Please contact the interventional pulmonary team if any airway issues occur in this patient. Anesthesia is also aware
-	Patient will require 3 times a day 3% saline nebulizers starting tonight and as long as the patient’s airway stent is in place for mucolytic effect and hydration to prevent stent plugging.
-	If tracheostomy tube needs to be removed and reinserted this must be performed  with direct visualization of the distal tip as it is inserted into the lumen of the tracheostomy tube to prevent kinking or obstruction of the stent by  the tracheostomy tube.
-	Please do not adjust the endotracheal tubes position or attempt suction unless absolutely necessary (tonight).
-	Extubation must be performed with flexible bronchoscope to allow visualization of the stent and using flexible forceps to apply downward pressure on the main carina while retracting the ETT to avoid dislodging of the stent.
-	If invasive ventilatory support is required after ETT removal blind intubation (direct laryngoscopy, glidescope) should be avoided as it can result in dislodgment of the tracheal stent and potential catastrophic airway obstruction.  Intubation should be performed with a 6.5 or smaller ETT with bronchoscopic insertion to visualize the distal tip of the endotracheal tube. The endotracheal tube should be advanced into the tracheal limb of the stent and secured.

clinical_context.primary_indication: Left mainstem obstruction secondary to esophageal stent migration
clinical_context.radiographic_findings: Esophageal stent migration through distal trachea and left mainstem

diagnostic_bronchoscopy.inspection_findings: Esophageal stent visualized protruding into trachea 2cm proximal to carina (30% obstruction). Inner covered stent lumen 50% into airway. Outer uncovered stent 5mm into distal left mainstem. Large clip visualized. Purulent secretions.

foreign_body_removal.foreign_body_type: Esophageal stent pieces (covered and uncovered), large clip

cao_interventions_detail.notes: Esophageal stent migration causing obstruction; removed piecemeal using scissors, APC, forceps.

complications.other_complication_details: Extension of TE fistula during stent extraction

outcomes.follow_up_plan_text: CXR in ICU, CT chest prior to extubation. Saline nebulizers 3x/day.

cpt_codes.description: Bronchoscopy; with placement of bronchial stent(s), initial bronchus (Y-stent primary)
Bronchoscopy; each additional major bronchus stented (Y-stent secondary limb)
Bronchoscopy; with removal of foreign body (esophageal stent pieces)

lines.description: Bronchoscopy; with placement of bronchial stent(s), initial bronchus
lines.selection_reason: Placement of Y-stent involving bronchial limbs (RMB/LMB); 31636 captures the initial bronchial limb of the Y-stent.

lines.description: Bronchoscopy; each additional major bronchus stented
lines.selection_reason: Placement of the second bronchial limb of the Y-stent.

lines.description: Bronchoscopy; with removal of foreign body
lines.selection_reason: Removal of migrated esophageal stent pieces and clip from the airway (distinct service from stent placement).
Diagnostic bronchoscopy and lavage are bundled into therapeutic bronchoscopy (31635/31636).

financial_analysis.notes: Estimated payments based on 2025 national unadjusted rates. Multiple endoscopy reduction likely applies to 31635.

per_code.summary: Y-stent placement typically involves stenting the mainstem bronchi. 31636 is used for the first stented bronchus.
Captures the second limb of the Y-stent in the contralateral mainstem bronchus.
Removal of the migrated esophageal stent and clip constitutes foreign body removal from the airway.

global_comments: Diagnostic bronchoscopy (31622) and lavage (31624/31622) are bundled into the therapeutic codes.
APC and mechanical destruction of the stent were part of the removal process (31635).
Two stent attempts occurred (one failed, one successful); only the successful placement is typically billed.
Y-stent coding varies by payer; 31636/+31637 is commonly used to reflect the bilateral bronchial work, though 31631 (Tracheal) is an alternative.

metadata.notes: Complex case involving esophageal stent removal from airway and Y-stent placement. Fistula extension noted as complication.

note_text:
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: 
1.	Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis 
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: 
1.	Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis 
PROCEDURE PERFORMED: 
1.	Flexible bronchoscopy 
2.	Left whole lung lavage

INDICATIONS: Dyspnea and hypoxia 
Consent was obtained from the patient prior to procedure after explanation in lay terms the indications, details of procedure, and potential risks and alternatives. The patient acknowledged and gave consent. 
Sedation: General Anesthesia
DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE: Once the patient was sedated and neuromuscularly relaxed a left sided double-lumen endotracheal tube was inserted into the airway.  Confirmation of placement was performed bronchoscopically and subsequently a catheter was connected to the bronchial port while single lung ventilation was performed through the tracheal port and submerged in saline to evaluate for any evidence of air leaking to the contralateral side and none was witnessed.  At this point the patient was placed in the reverse Trendelenburg position and we began by instilling 1 L of warm saline into the left-sided bronchial port of the double-lumen tube.  Following installation chest percussion was performed for approximately 4 minutes at which time the patients bed was repositioned in the Trendelenburg position and gravity dependent drainage of the fluid began.  Initial fluid cloudy with a significant sediment as expected and pulmonary alveolar proteinosis.  This process was repeated multiple times, after approximately 3 L of instillation and 2200cc of drainage low suction was attached intermittently through the drainage port to assist with fluid removal.  We continue to perform lavages to maintain a maximal post installation positive balance of no more than 1200 cc to prevent barotrauma and possible pneumothorax.  After approximately 8 L of insulation and 7200 cc of return the fluid had cleared to the point where there was only a minimal cloudiness and no evidence of active sedimentation indicating that the procedure was successful and no further lavage was necessary.  At this point the case was turned over to anesthesia for immersion and extubation.  Post extubation the patient was hypoxic to the high 80s on noninvasive ventilation as well as extremely combative and decision was made to watch the patient in the ICU rather than the ward overnight.

Complications: none
Recommendations:
-	Transferred to the ICU for overnight observation
-	Obtain chest x-ray now and in 4 hours to evaluate for pneumothorax
-	The patient does well overnight located discharge tomorrow
-	Plan for right-sided lavage in approximately 2 weeks

complications.other_complication_details: Post-extubation combativeness and hypoxia requiring ICU admission

outcomes.follow_up_plan_text: CXR now and in 4 hours. Plan for right-sided lavage in 2 weeks.

lines.selection_reason: Primary procedure performed: Left whole lung lavage.
Bronchoscopy performed solely for confirmation of DLT placement is considered integral to the lavage procedure/anesthesia and not separately reportable.

financial_analysis.notes: RVU data for CPT 32997 is not present in the provided fee schedule source files. Financial totals are 0.

documentation_evidence.snippet: Left whole lung lavage... instilling 1 L of warm saline... Total 8 L

per_code.summary: Bundled. Documentation states 'Confirmation of placement was performed bronchoscopically', which is integral to DLT placement and the lavage procedure.

documentation_evidence.snippet: Confirmation of placement was performed bronchoscopically

rules_applied.description: Diagnostic bronchoscopy is bundled when performed with therapeutic procedures or for tube placement.

global_comments: Procedure performed under General Anesthesia; moderate sedation codes (99152/99153) are not applicable.
Post-procedure hypoxia/combativeness noted as complications affecting disposition.

note_text:
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: 
1.	Resolving Mediastinal Mass 
2.	Airway stent partial obstruction from granulation tissue
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: 
1.	Resolving Mediastinal Mass  status post tracheal Y-stent removal
PROCEDURE PERFORMED: 
1.	Rigid and flexible bronchoscopy with  Tracheal stent removal
2.	Cryotherapy for debulking of granulation tissue
INDICATIONS:  resolution of airway compression 
Consent was obtained from the patient prior to procedure after explanation in lay terms the indications, details of procedure, and potential risks and alternatives. The patient acknowledged and gave consent. 
Sedation: General Anesthesia
DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE: DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE: The procedure was performed in the main operating room. Following intravenous medications as per the record a laryngeal mask airway was inserted. Topical anesthesia was then applied to the upper airway and the T190 video bronchoscope was introduced through the mouth, via laryngeal mask airway and advanced to the tracheobronchial tree. The laryngeal mask airway was in good position. The vocal cords appeared normal. The subglottic space was normal. The patient’s Y stent was well placed.  There was no granulation tissue visualized at the proximal tracheal tip which was 2cm distal to the vocal cords. Moderate thick mucus was seen throughout the stent which was suctioned. At the distal aspect of the right mainstem limb was normal without granulation tissue. At the distal aspect of the left mainstem limb there was granulation tissue causing about 30% obstruction.  At this point the flexible bronchoscope and LMA were removed and a 12 mm non-ventilating rigid tracheoscope was inserted through the mouth into the sub-glottic space. The rigid optical forceps were inserted through the rigid scope. The forceps were used to grasp the proximal limb of the tracheal but due to some minor bleeding it was difficult to visualize adequately and the rigid optics were removed. Flexible bronchoscope was then inserted into the rigid tracheoscope to remove secretions. The non-optical rigid forceps were then inserted alongside the rigid optic and the stent was grasped and then were rotated repeatedly while withdrawing the stent into the rigid bronchoscope.  The stent and rigid bronchoscope were subsequently removed without difficulty. The stent was fully intact.  Once his stent was removed the LMA was reinserted and the the flexible bronchoscope was reinserted. The 1.9mm flexible cryoprobe was inserted through the working channel and cryotherapy was performed in the areas of granulation tissue in the mid left mainstem with 30 second freeze thaw times and at least 3 activations per site. At this point the flexible bronchoscope was removed and the procedure was completed. 
Complications: None
Recommendations:
- Transfer back to PACU and then to pediatric wards

diagnostic_bronchoscopy.inspection_findings: Vocal cords normal. Subglottic space normal. Y stent in place. No proximal granulation. Thick mucus in stent. RMS normal. LMS distal granulation tissue (30% obstruction).

complications.other_complication_details: Minor bleeding noted during rigid grasping, resolved.

outcomes.follow_up_plan_text: Transfer to PACU then pediatric wards

note_text:
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: 
1.	Severe tracheobronchomalacia 
2.	Airway stent partial obstruction from granulation tissue
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: 
1.	Severe tracheobronchomalacia  status post tracheal Y-stent removal
PROCEDURE PERFORMED: 
1.	Rigid and flexible bronchoscopy with  Tracheal stent removal
2.	Cryotherapy to granulation tissue
INDICATIONS:  Airway stent partial obstruction from granulation tissue
Consent was obtained from the patient prior to procedure after explanation in lay terms the indications, details of procedure, and potential risks and alternatives. The patient acknowledged and gave consent. 
Sedation: General Anesthesia
DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE: DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE: The procedure was performed in the main operating room. Once the patient was sedated and paralyzed a 12 mm non-ventilating rigid tracheoscope was inserted through the mouth into the sub-glottic space. A flexible T190 Olympus bronchoscope was inserted through the tracheoscope into the trachea and airway inspection was performed. The patient’s Y stent was well placed.  There was thick purulent mucous throughout the stent which was suctioned. At the distal aspect of the right mainstem limb there was granulation tissue causing about 50% obstruction and at the distal aspect of the left mainstem limb there was granulation tissue causing about 60%   after bypassing the granulation tissue there were thick copious purulent secretions through the lower lobes which were suctioned. The flexible bronchoscope was removed and the rigid optical forceps were inserted through the rigid scope. The forceps were used to grasp the proximal limb of the tracheal stent and were rotated repeatedly while withdrawing the stent into the rigid bronchoscope.  The stent was subsequently removed without difficulty and was fully intact.  Once his stent was removed the flexible bronchoscope was reinserted for repeat airway inspection. There was significant (near complete dynamic airway collapse of the trachea and mainstem bronchi as expected given known TBM.  The 1.9mm flexible cryoprobe was inserted through the working channel and cryotherapy was performed in the areas of granulation tissue with 30 second freeze thaw times and at least 3 activations per site. At this point the rigid bronchoscope was removed and the procedure was completed. 
Complications: None
Recommendations:
- Transfer back to PACU and then to wards
-  Plan for stent holiday to allow healing of granulation tissue and based on symptoms possible replacement of the stent sometime in the future.

metadata.notes: Procedure performed in OR under General Anesthesia. Stent holiday initiated.
